chapter.title: Bootique and Testing
chapter.para: Bootique is uniquely suitable to be used as a test framework. Within a single test it allows you to start and stop multiple embedded stacks with distinct set of modules and distinct YAML configurations, making it a powerful tool for integration testing. Bootique core module and some other modules provide companion test extensions that contain reusable test stacks.

chapter.title: Creating Test Stacks
chapter.para: To use basic Bootique test framework, import the following module in the "test" scope:<dependency> <groupId>com.nhl.bootique</groupId> <artifactId>bootique-test</artifactId> <scope>test</scope> </dependency>For module-specific "companion" test frameworks (e.g. bootique-jetty-test), check documentation of those modules or GitHub.
You won't need to stop it explicitly. BQDaemonTestFactory will take care of it via JUnit lifecycle.

In real test suites creating configurators for every test becomes unwieldy rather quickly. So consider subclassing BQDaemonTestFactory or BQTestFactory to reuse configurators common for your entire app.

chapter.title: Common Test Scenarios
chapter.para: Now that we can start stacks on foreground or background, we can finally write some tests. Some things that can be tested include runtime services with real dependencies, standard output of full Bootique applications (i.e. the stuff that would be printed to console if this were a real app), network services using real network connections (e.g. your REST API's), and so on.
